content: Now that's your public education system at work right there! That was just painful to read. I don't even know where to start. I started to say I will stay with the obvious, but would be EVERYTHING. So... I will approach the UCMJ issue. The UCMJ applies to members of the military. If you do not carry a DD Form 2 in your wallet, you are not in the military. If you do not have some alpha/numeric conotation attached to your name, you are not in the military (E-1 thru E-10, W-1 thru W-5 or O-1 thru O-10). If you do not frequently play dress up in some form which indludes the colors blue or green or clevely disguised as a tree, you are not in the military. Now it is interesting to have the discussions. I remember the same discussion being held about President Clinton's various escapades. But as a matter of law, the UCMJ does not apply to POTUS. This message has been edited. Last edited by: 2494906, Fri 06 March 2009 02:54 PM
reply: Now that's your public education system at work right there! That was just painful to read. I don't even know where to start. I started to say I will stay with the obvious, but would be EVERYTHING. So... I will approach the UCMJ issue. The UCMJ applies to members of the military. If you do not carry a DD Form 2 in your wallet, you are not in the military. If you do not have some alpha/numeric conotation attached to your name, you are not in the military (E-1 thru E-10, W-1 thru W-5 or O-1 thru O-10). If you do not frequently play dress up in some form which indludes the colors blue or green or clevely disguised as a tree, you are not in the military. Now it is interesting to have the discussions. I remember the same discussion being held about President Clinton's various escapades. But as a matter of law, the UCMJ does not apply to POTUS. This message has been edited. Last edited by: 2494906, Fri 06 March 2009 02:54 PM
title: Undercover racist

content: Good grief, people...this is taken from the Military.com article about the young lieutenant who has allegedly refused to recognize the President as being legitimate. The entire quote from the article: Attorney Mathew B. Tully of the Washington, D.C.-based firm Tully Rinckey PLLC, cautioned "that nobody's actually heard directly from this ... lieutenant. We're getting this from a third party with an axe to grind." It has happened in the past, he said, that stories emerging from the combat theater turn out to be wholly or partially false. If true, however, Easterling, as an Army officer, "is subject to ... [provisions] against using contemptuous language toward the president." There were such incidents in the 1990s, he said, when service members were disciplined for comments made against President Clinton. In one case brought under the provisions of Article 88 of the UCMJ a major general was forced to retire for comments he made, Tully said. Easterling also could be charged with conduct unbecoming an officer, he said. If an officer actually believes there has been some misconduct by the president, Tully said, there are ways he could have responded. Under Article 138, he said, any person can bring an allegation of misconduct by a commander through the chain of command, "though I don't think [it] has ever been used to allege misconduct by the president." ...OK? I believe the poster is upset over the posters and others who are vehemently opposed to Obama's Presidency. He appears to be particularly bothered by the fact that, since Obama has only been in office for a month, the opposition can't be based on anything he's done, but who he is. And he holds up Bush and his record (because there's an eight-year body of work available) to show misconduct by a commander.
